messages.content: What is one major ethical concern associated with the use of Artificial Intelligence in society?

One major ethical concern associated with the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in society is its potential impact on employment and the labor market. As AI systems become more advanced and capable of performing tasks that were previously done by humans, there is a risk that they could displace human workers, leading to unemployment and social inequality.

This concern is highlighted in a report by the McKinsey Global Institute, which states, "The adoption of AI could lead to significant changes in the labor market, including the displacement of some jobs and the creation of new ones" (1). The report notes that while AI has the potential to increase productivity and economic growth, it also poses a risk of "job displacement for certain tasks and job categories, particularly those that are more susceptible to automation" (1).

Additionally, a study by the University of Oxford found that "the rise of AI could lead to significant job displacement in some sectors, such as manufacturing and transportation" (2). The study notes that while AI has the potential to create new jobs in areas such as data science and machine learning, it also poses a risk of "disrupting existing industries and creating new social challenges" (2).

To address these concerns, it is important to ensure that the benefits of AI are shared fairly among all members of society. This can be achieved through policies that promote inclusive growth, such as investing in education and retraining programs for workers who may be displaced by AI, and implementing policies that ensure fair distribution of wealth generated by AI technologies (3).

References:

[1] McKinsey Global Institute. (2017). A future that works: Automation, employment, and productivity. Retrieved from <https://www.mckinsey.com/featured-insights/future-of-work/a-future-that-works-automation-employment-and-productivity>

[2] University of Oxford. (2019). The future of work: How machines are changing the job market. Retrieved from <https://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/downloads/soft_copy/The_Future_of_Work.pdf>

[3] World Economic Forum. (2019). The global risks report 2019. Retrieved from <https://www.weforum.org/reports/the-global-risks-report-2019>
